channel.title: Censorship – Baraza
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: Archives and Canons
item.dc:creator: Max Shmookler
item.description: What is the opposite of a canon? Perhaps an archive, which contains an overwhelming array of texts that very few people intend to read. I sometimes feel like Raph and I are working our way through an immaterial archive that stretches across the globe. This “archive” contains digital copies of short stories culled from published … Continue reading Archives and Canons →

item.title: Watch the Throne: The Moroccan Monarchy’s Mic Check
item.dc:creator: Chantal James
item.description: This July Morocco celebrated Throne Day, in celebration of King Mohammed VI’s ascension to the throne thirteen years ago. He seems to have much to celebrate; time and again, the crown asserts itself as secure against threats large and small. What has been the Moroccan monarchy’s secret to maintaining power in a post-Bouazizi world, when … Continue reading Watch the Throne: The Moroccan Monarchy’s Mic Check →

item.title: Politics of Labeling and Marginalization: Deconstructing Islamic Feminist Discourse
item.dc:creator: Chantal James
item.description: According to Foucault, the production of discourse in every society is simultaneously controlled, organized, selected and redistributed according to particular procedures. These procedures are meant to “avert its [the discourse’s] power and its dangers, to cope with change events, and to evade its ponderous and awesome materiality.”I Islamic feminist discourse is no different. Just like any … Continue reading Politics of Labeling and Marginalization: Deconstructing Islamic Feminist Discourse →

item.title: Monitoring Muslims
item.dc:creator: barazaonline
item.description: NYPD surveillance of Muslims, particularly the surveillance which occurred on college campuses (including Columbia University), is controversial in part because of the strong rhetoric on both sides of the issue. The arguments weigh civil liberties with an emphasis on free exercise of religion against concerns for safety and national security. This is an old battle … Continue reading Monitoring Muslims →

item.title: Libyan Media: In Chaos or Right Where it Should Be?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rghebi
item.description: After 42 years under the tight grip of Muammar al-Gaddafi, Libya is not only experiencing a political revolution but also a media revolution. The tightly controlled state-run media of the Gaddafi regime allowed no room for free expression or criticism. As the revolution which began in February of 2011 spread across Libya, numerous media outlets … Continue reading Libyan Media: In Chaos or Right Where it Should Be? →
